div.ab: With Freedom is thy struggle, O Evil One: it can cast on thee a muzzle, if it so please.
Response: To Thee be glory in whose victory we have gained strength: and in whose resurrection we defy even Death itself!
Lo! again these two exposed each other, how weak both are: Death reminded the Evil One of thy mightiness (O Freedom).
Thy fire is in thy nest, O Death, and thou perceivest not: the fate of the departed, to thee is overthrow.
Lo! Death and the Evil One proclaim thy mightiness (O Freedom): yea, the Evil One calls to mind thy faith.
If then these that were against thee are on thy side: this is a great thing that thy persecutors have become thy heralds,
Death: I confess, O Evil One, that as usury: I lay up the King’s treasures, till His Coming.
Satan: I, O Death, rather deny that this belongs to God: this treasure of subtlety, which I have stored.
Death: Thy coinage is fraudulent, then, O Satan: that into the treasuries of God, is not received.
Satan: A new coinage do I coin, in kingly wise: lo! my merchantmen bring loss, into the world.
God created everything out of nothing: and I created great sin out of nothing
Death: Closed and bound be thy mouth, Evil One, who art thus bold: to set thyself, lo! in comparison with the Creator.
Satan: To me, O Death, it is lawful to dare and speak: thy tongue, even thine, is a slave, and under fear.
Death: A gulf is henceforth between us, O Satan: for madly against thy Lord, lo! thou assailest.
Satan: Wherefore doubtest thou, O Death, of our concord? Be to us comrade and member: and lo! we reign.
Come, draw we our pair of swords, against mankind: I secretly, thou openly, and lo! we end them.
Sin and Sheol they too gave counsel to those two: saying “If ye be divided, ye are undone.”
See the waters how if dispersed, they run low: but if gathered they gain strength, and thus ye likewise.
If divided ye perish, as the feeble: but yoked together ye reign, as the mighty.
Love melts down many, as in a furnace: and makes one powerful mass, that overcomes all.
In it are wisdom and cunning, and force and power: it is greater far than an image of sixty cubits.
Be reconciled, let us assemble and go, against that party: which if it be at one can never be defeated.
These things the troublers discoursed, and gathered and came: Thy day, Lord, will gather them, into Gehenna.
Through Thy mercy, Lord, will I worship Thee, when I have risen: at Thy trumpet I will praise Thy Son, when I am purged.
